headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Special Counsel Robert Hur Testifies Regarding Biden Classified Documents Probe; Hur Questioned About Classified Info at Biden's Home. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Mr. Hur. The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from North Dakota for five minutes.REP. KELLY ARMSTRONG (R-ND):  Thank you, Mr. Chairman. How could that possibly happen? How could anyone be that irresponsible? And I thought, what data was in there that could compromise sources, methods, and it's just totally irresponsible. As President Biden's statement about Donald Trump and the classified documents. Mr. Hur, classified documents were found at the Penn Biden Center?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: They were found in President Biden's garage?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: In Wilmington, Delaware, yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And in his basement den?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Also in the same home, yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And his main floor office?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And his third floor den?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: At the University of Delaware?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And at the Biden Institute?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.[10:40:00] ARMSTRONG:  All right. And the elements of the crime for this, I mean, we can't -- we get into all of this, but the elements of the crime are pretty simple, right? The President -- President Biden had unauthorized possession of a document writing or note, that's correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And that the document writing or note related to national defense.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And that the defendant, and we may talk about the willfully part here in a second, retained the document writing or note and failed to deliver it to an employee or officer entitled to receive it?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct, there is a willfulness intent element, as you say.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And -- but those are the elements of the crime?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Including the intent element, yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And there are at least two different quotes, right, where he told this ghostwriter -- and this is in your report, in a matter of fact -- and this is February 16, 2017, that he had just found all this classified stuff downstairs.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: He did make that statement that was captured on an audio recording.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And on April 10, 2017, Biden read aloud a classified passage related to a 2015 meeting in the situation room.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is in the report, yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And these are national security documents. Afghanistan -- I mean, has been mentioned, a whole bunch of those things, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And at one point in time, his personal attorneys and the DOJ attorneys argued about notes, taking all of the different things and compared it to Reagan?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. Could you repeat that, Congressman?

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: President Biden's attorneys, personal attorneys, talked about the notes and why they didn't actually account for the Presidential Records Act. But you -- I mean, you found that argument, I -- in your report, it seems a little persuasive, but you eventually said, no, the executive order Trump's, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We did conduct -- we did set forth an analysis of the governing law and ultimately concluded that the executive order 13526 does apply and did govern Former Vice President Biden at the time. JORDAN

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We have an audio recording capturing a statement from Mr. Biden saying to his ghostwriter in February of 2017, "I just found all the classified stuff downstairs".

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: OK. And then again, reciting passages from a meeting in the situation room?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: And those are in President Biden's own words?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: Right. So, he's -- again, the ghostwriter has no classified -- no -- he has no clearance -- no classified clearance to anything, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is our understanding that Mr. Zwonitzer was not authorized to receive classified information.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: OK. So, the elements are possessed documents, the documents related to national defense, and willfully retained those documents. And in this case, shared them with somebody who was not allowed to receive them.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: There are different subsections of 18 U.S.C. 793. One subsection relates to the willful retention, and another relates to disclosure of national defense information.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: Well, though -- I mean, the willful retention. We've got the Penn Biden Center, the garage, the basement den, the main floor office, the third floor den, the University of Delaware, and the Biden Institute. We have a 50-year career of a person who has not been very great at dealing with classified documents throughout, even prior to his time as vice president, when he was in the U.S. Senate, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We do address each set of those documents in the report, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: So, the difference -- but I think this is really important because the difference is, it appears just from reading the report, he has been -- we heard all about exonerated and all those different things. It appears from the report, he met every actual element of the crime.So, I want to talk about, the department principles on federal prosecution. because that actually has nothing to do with the underlying elements, correct? It's whether or not you can prove this at trial.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Under the department's justice manual and the principles of federal prosecution, a prosecutor has to assess the evidence and determine whether in his or her judgment, the likely -- the probable outcome will be a conviction at trial.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: So, whether or not you meet the elements of the crime, which I think it's clear that it does, the second part of this is this. And that's where it gets into the sympathetic, well-meaning elderly man with a poor memory. You could have just said, we don't prosecute sitting presidents, but you did not, and you entered this.But that doesn't have anything to do with the actual elements of the crime. That has to do with getting a conviction at trial, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Well, Congressman, part and parcel of a prosecutor's judgment as to whether or not a conviction is the probable outcome of a trial is assessing how the evidence identified during the investigation lines up with the elements and what proof can be offered to a jury during a trial.

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: Sure, but his well-meaning elderly old man has nothing to do with the underlying elements of the crime?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Well, it certainly has something --

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: It's a presentation to the jury.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It certainly has something --

utterances.speaker: ARMSTRONG
utterances.sentences: I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman can respond.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It certainly has something to do with the way that a jury is going to perceive and receive, and consider and -- make conclusions based on evidence at trial, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The time of the gentleman has expired. The Chair now recognizes the ranking member of the Judiciary Committee, Mr. Nadler.REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY):  Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Mr. Hur, in your written testimony, you say that you found some evidence that the President might have willfully retained classified materials at the end of his vice presidency, correct?

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: But ultimately, you concluded that you could not prove that charge in the court of law. In your words, you quote, "Did not identify evidence that rose to the level of proof beyond a reasonable doubt", correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That was my judgment.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: You have been a prosecutor for a long time, Mr. Hur. Would you agree that there's no such thing as being a little bit charged for a crime? You're either charged or you're not, correct? HUR

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Would you agree that there's no such thing as being a little bit charged for a crime? You're either charged or you are not charged, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is binary. Either one is not charged --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: -- or charged.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: So, just to be clear, because so many people have taken your words out of context, your ultimate conclusion was that President Biden could not be charged with a crime because even after your thorough investigation, you could not find sufficient evidence to charge him, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: My conclusion was that based on my evaluation of the evidence, as a prosecutor --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Don't feel -- it was correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Congressman, I didn't hear your last question.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: I said, based on your conclusion, your ultimate conclusion is that President Biden could not be charged with a crime because even after your thorough investigation, you could not find sufficient evidence to charge him, correct or not correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: My ultimate conclusion was that criminal charges were not warranted.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Correct. Now, let's talk about why -- I have limited time, so please, when I say correct just -- or not correct, answer the question.Now, let's talk about why, in sharp contrast to President Biden, President Trump faces 40 charges related to the unlawful retention of highly classified documents. That is, of course, apart from the additional 51 counts in cases alleging that he incited a rebellion and lied about his finances. You found that President Biden reported the possible classified documents in his possession to the FBI as soon as he learned of them, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: There was a voluntary disclosure by the President's counsel to authorities relating to the discovery of classified documents at the Penn Bidens.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Let's contrast this with President Trump. Are you aware that the FBI only learned that Trump was in possession of classified material after the National Archives discovered them?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I am not intimately familiar with the facts relating to Former President Trump. I'm prepared to comment on them to the extent that I address them in the report. NADLER

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That was a factor in our analysis, yes.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. By way of contrast, to the best of your knowledge, why did the Department of Justice seek a warrant to search Mar-a-Lago?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I am not familiar with those deliberations. That is a matter that I had no participation in --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll tell you it was because they were concerned that Trump had lied about possession of those documents and might conceal or destroy them.Special Counsel Smith found that President Trump obstructed his investigation by suggesting that his attorney falsely represented the FBI and grand jury, that Trump did not have the documents called for by the grand jury subpoena. At any point in your investigation, you -- do you have any reason to believe that President Biden lied to you?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I do address in my report one response the President gave to a question that we had posed to him that we deemed to be not credible.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Was it clear he didn't lie?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: The report is clear that he didn't lie, or that he caused his staff to lie to you, and that he didn't cause his staff to lie to you. Your report is clear on that.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I did not --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Do you agree that causing someone to lie to the FBI is a classic example of obstruction of justice?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It is an example of obstruction, yes.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Trump also obstructed the Smith investigation by directing one of his employees to move boxes of documents to conceal them from Trump's attorney, from the FBI, and from the grand jury. At any point in your investigation, did you find that President Biden directed his staff to conceal documents from you or anyone else?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We did not reach that conclusion.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: OK. You would agree that hiding documents is a classic example of obstructing an investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It is an example of obstruction. NADLER

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I don't want to characterize the evidence in the case against former president --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: But if that happened, would you agree that the leading video footage is plainly an attempt to obstruct an investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, it's the type of evidence that prosecutors would consider and --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: OK. To sum up, Donald Trump is charged with willfully retaining classified documents and conspiring to conceal those documents, and he's facing additional charges for lying to investigators. Isn't that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Those are allegations that are in a pending --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: It's a matter of public record.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: And the reason why President Biden is not facing a single charge, Mr. Hur, is not because you went easy on him, but because after reviewing 7 million documents and interviewing nearly 150 witnesses, including the President himself, you could not prove that he had committed a crime. I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Gentleman yields back. The gentleman from -- Mr. McClintock, gentleman from California, is recognized.REP. TOM MCCLINTOCK (R-CA):  Thank you. Mr. Hur, I first want to get this straight. Is it now OK if I take- home top-secret documents, store them in my garage, and read portions of them to friends or associates?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I wouldn't recommend it, but I don't want to entertain any hypotheticals at this point.

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: Well, is it OK -- I mean, I can do that now under this new doctrine?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Again, Congressman, I wouldn't recommend that you do that, but I don't want to --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: Well, you -- you've essentially said so in your report. And certainly, it would be exculpatory if I simply told you, hey, I'm getting old. I don't remember stuff the way I used to.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I'm not here to get into hypotheticals. I'm here to talk about the facts and the work that I did --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not a hypothetical. This is the issue at hand. You correctly noted in your report that former presidents and other senior officials have been given wide latitude in their possession of classified information. And I believe your decision to -- not to prosecute Biden for the same offense is consistent with that precedent.But the problem is that precedent changed with the administration's decision to prosecute Donald Trump. And the irony is that as president, Trump had full discretion over handling classified material and full discretion in deciding which records to retain. As a senator or vice president, Joe Biden didn't have that. So, now we get to this glaring double standard. I think it would be toxic to the rule of law on its face if it was just two ordinary citizens. But the fact that the only person being prosecuted for this offense happens to be the President's political opponent makes this an unprecedented assault on our democracy. This is the worst we could expect from a Banana Republic (ph). And I wonder how you square this.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I do address, as I was required to as a prosecutor, a relevant precedent in the form of the alleged -- the allegations in the indictment against former President Trump. I set forth my explanation and my assessment and comparison of those precedents in my report. And I am not here to comment any further beyond what's in my report.

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: Well, you said, for example, that there was no evidence beyond reasonable doubt. Well, you got the fact that he had classified material in his possession and control in multiple settings for multiple years. That he told others he was aware of this, and that he shared that material with others. The mind boggles at what beyond reasonable doubt would actually mean.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Well, as I set forth in -- at length in my explanations in chapters 11 and 12 of the report, my assessment is that the evidence, if presented at trial alongside potential defense arguments, would not probably result in a conviction at trial.

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: Well, that's one of the points you make is that President Biden is likely to be an elderly, sympathetic figure with a poor memory. But how does that bear on any individual's guilt or innocence? Isn't that again a question for a judge or jury to decide after guilt or innocence is determined?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It is --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: And again, here's the problem, Donald Trump's being prosecuted for exactly the same act that you've documented that Joe Biden committed.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, if I understood your question correctly, you said, isn't that a question for a jury? And it most certainly, in the -- through the lens of my --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: My question is, does that bear on the guilt or innocence of an individual?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It certainly bears on how a jury is going to receive and perceive and make decisions --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: So, the answer to my earlier question is correct? All I have to do when I'm caught taking home classified materials is to say, I'm sorry, Mr. Hur, but I'm getting old. My memory's not so great.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I --

utterances.speaker: MCCLINTOCK
utterances.sentences: This is the doctrine that you've established in our laws now, and it's frightening.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, my intent is certainly not to establish any sort of doctrine. I had a particular task. I have a particular set of evidence to consider and make a judgment with respect to one particular set of evidence, and that is what I did.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The gentleman yields back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Chairman, I ask for unanimous consent to introduce the State of the Union as an exhibit at the end of the hearing.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The -- without objection, that will be introduced.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The ranking members recognize for unanimous consent.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, I ask unanimous consent that a copy of an article in this morning's "Washington Post" entitled, "Full Transcript of Biden's Special Counsel Interview Paints Nuanced Portrait". The president's -- the president doesn't come across as absent minded as Hur has made him out to be.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Without objection.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The Chair recognizes -- now recognizes the gentlelady from California for five minutes.REP. ZOE LOFGREN (D-CA):  Thank you, Mr. Chairman. And thank you, Mr. Hur, for being here today. I found your report very interesting, and I learned some things about it, the law and the precedence. There are clear differences between the cases of -- and precedence set by Presidents Reagan, Trump, and Biden. Now, it was widely known that President Reagan kept diaries from his presidency that included classified information. What I didn't know and learned in your report was that the Department of Justice, "Repeatedly described the diaries in public court filings as Mr. Reagan's personal records", and that no agency ever attempted to remove his diaries. That's on page 195 of your report. Very interesting. So, the investigation found that President Biden believed that his notebooks were his personal property, including work and political notes, reflections, to do lists, and more, that he was entitled to take home. You found that on page 232. So, while much of his notebook was work related, he still had some purely personal subjects like, again, I quote, "Gut-wrenching", entities about the illness and death of his son, Beau, and that's on page 82 and 253 of your report. So, it's clear, based on the Reagan precedent that no criminal charges were warranted in this matter, relative to personal notebooks. Now, I want to be clear that although the notebooks contain some very personal information, and President Biden considered them his personal property, the President allowed your team to seize and review all of the notebooks you found. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: Now, that's in stark contrast to ex-President Trump's case. He obstructed and diverted all the investigations. Now, you also interviewed President Biden about other classified documents you found outside his notebooks, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes, Congresswoman.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: So, did the President tell you that he believed any documents other than his own handwritten work were his personal property, yes or no?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We did not hear that from the President during his interview.
